Award.AwardTitle: The Development of Microelectrode Arrays as Bioanalytical Tools

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1262176
Moeller

Microelectrode arrays are potentially powerful tools for monitoring interactions between small molecule libraries and biological receptors. They hold two main advantages over current state-of-the-art methods. First, they can be used to detect binding events as they occur without the need for a labeled receptor or immunological assay. The result is a cost effective, rapid method for analysis that enables the use of biological data to interactively guide the design and synthesis of new receptor ligands. Second, the microelectrodes in an array can be used to reclaim molecules from the surface of the electrodes. Hence, molecules in a library that give rise to a biological signal can be isolated and characterized. This allows for quality control of the library. With these advances in mind, new chemistry for the site-selective placement, manipulation, and monitoring of molecules on the surface of a microelectrode array have been developed. In this project we will further build up the repertoire of tools by developing chemistry for direct synthesis of molecular libraries, porous membranes that will cover electrodes to minimize nonspecific binding and will demonstrate proof of concept use of novel electrode arrays for screening small molecules.

General public statement:
This project will develop technologies based on electrode arrays to enable creation and testing of drug candidate molecules. This technology is interesting in that it can be used at all stages from biomolecule synthesis to its release to screening of biomolecule-target interactions.

This project is being funded by the Nano-Biosensing Program in the CBET Division of the ENG directorate, with co-funding from both the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program and the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) Program in the CHE Division of the MPS directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microelectrode arrays are powerful tools for monitoring a wide variety of biological binding interactions and events. They have been used to monitor cell migration on surfaces, to develop tissue engineering models, to measure binding events between drugs and receptors, to probe the protein-protein interactions central for cell signaling, etc. The methods allow us monitor binding events in “real-time” as they happen and in so doing afford more accurate data. Many of the experiments are based on the overall approach highlighted in the Figure provided. In this approach, molecules (represented by the shapes) are attached to the array so that each unique member of a molecular library is located by a unique electrode in the array. The array is then placed along with a second, remote electrode in a solution that contains a molecule that can be both oxidized and reduced. The molecule is oxidized at the array and reduced again at the remote electrode to set up a current that can be measured at each one of the electrodes. A biological target is then added to the solution. When it binds a molecule on the array, the binding event blocks the current and this change can be immediately detected and the binding event recorded.   

            As powerful as these methods can be, we are still only scratching the surface of their potential because their use requires that we carefully construct a complex molecular surface on the array. This is an extremely difficult challenge. How does one make the library of molecules like the one shown in the cartoon above when the array has over 12,000 electrodes per square centimeter? To answer this question, our NSF funded effort has been developing the synthetic chemistry tools necessary to construct such complex surfaces. The work has taught us how to carry out chemical reactions at any single electrode or pattern of electrodes in an array and how to control the amount of the material associated with each one of those electrodes. We have developed stable surfaces so that molecules built or placed on the arrays can be effectively studied, we have demonstrated that the use of these tools can lead to new bioanalytical experiments, and we have shown how to characterize anything built on an array so that the quality of those bioanalytical experiments can be verified. The methods developed enable us to use on the arrays the same synthetic toolbox that chemists now employ for the construction of complex molecules, pharmaceuticals, and new materials.

 

Broader Impact: The broader impacts of the work are two-fold. The first is scientific. The ability to control the surface of a microelectrode array allows for its use in a variety of experiments with far reaching significance. For example, in other projects our group is using the arrays to optimize binding events with proteins on the surface of breast cancer cells so that the cells can be detected early in the development of a tumor and to probe the cell signaling events that are central to the development of cancer cells in uveal melanoma. The array surfaces employed in these studies are build using the chemical tools developed by this NSF program. The second broader impact is educational. Because of our NSF funded efforts aimed at better understanding the interplay between the fields of organic synthesis and electrochemistry, our group has become a resource for scientists to learn about organic electrochemistry. In addition to our normal outreach (working with zoos and science centers) and teaching of electrochemical short-courses, our lab hosts students and scientists from both within the US and around the world who want to learn first-hand how to conduct electroorganic reactions.
